newsitem.title: UK: Quake-proof buildings needed fast, experts says.
newsitem.headline: Quake-proof buildings needed fast, experts says.

text.p: New earthquake-proof buildings are needed quickly in threatened cities and older buildings should be upgraded fast, an expert said on Wednesday.
Engineers and city planners should act before the lessons learned in the Japanese city of Kobe fade, Adrian Chandler, a civil engineer at University College London, said.
The January 1995 Kobe earthquake killed 6,000 people and caused $130 billion worth of damage, but would not be unique, Chandler wrote in a commentary for the science journal Nature.
"There is little doubt that an earthquake with similar destructive force could, and probably will, hit Tokyo within the next 20 years," Chandler wrote.

"The damage levels in pre-1971 buildings in the worst-hit parts of Kobe are representative of those to be expected in any future earthquake in a large Japanese or U.S. city, and in other earthquake-prone regions of the world."
It was not too expensive to build a new quake-resistant building, but of course no city could afford to replace all its buildings.
"The urgent need to upgrade the older, badly designed building stock is evident in all of the main earthquake zones in the world," Chandler said.

"There is a widespread view among engineers that owners and developers must demonstrate greater willingness in the future to pay for proper engineering design and construction to ensure a safe structure," he warned.
"Action is required sooner rather than later to prevent a repeat in other earthquake-threatened cities."

For instance, he said, using rubber bearings at the base of columns holding up buildings could help -- the only two such buildings in Kobe survived the quake, although they were a long way from the epicentre.
But the use of reinforced steel was being questioned, as many of the buildings that succumbed in Kobe had severe damage to welded steel plates.
Chandler wrote before Saturday's earthquake in north-east Iran, which killed more than 1,500 people.
